advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert puts forward network capabilities of Televideo systems.<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... If you want a personal computer that gives you professional performances, it's obvious that you have a lot of choices for today.<br> But there's only one with choices for tomorrow. Televideo ...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #3 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The guy on the right is "Sidney", a well known french break dancer back in 1984 !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"French people talking to french people"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART</strong></font><br><blockquote>This document compares the different Panasonic systems of the serie<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1986 price list:<br> Monochrome - Single drive: <b>£399</b> + VAT<br> Monochrome - Dual drive: <b>£499</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Single drive: <b>£549</b> + VAT<br> Colour - Dual drive: <b>£649</b> + VAT<br><br> Optional 10 MB hard disk: <b>£300</b> + VAT </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, AUGUST 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, August 1983 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>"For 1690 FF, wire all your family to the Laser 310"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NOT REALLY AN IMSAI!</strong></font><br><blockquote>In october 1979, the IMSAI company went bankrupt. The IMSAI brand name and the spare parts stock were sold to the <b>Fischer-Freitas</b> Company. <br><br> This 1982 advert shows a Z80 CP/M based computer Fisher-Freitas tried to sell with the IMSAI name, without success.<br><br> Fisher-Freitas is still selling original parts for the 8080 model! and continue maintaining a nice 8080 history web site (see the Web links section).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert shows all the tools a software developer could run on the MorthStar computers range (Horizon and Advantage) </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computers with a cool teacher" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>

computer.description:
Not much is known about this UK single board computer, also called PT-502. It was available only on loan to Open University students. The purpose was to teach electronic and computer engineers students how to conceive and build a microprocessor based system. The system was delivered with a peripheral board and a complete course enabling students to experiment both software and hardware problems.
More info needed about Model 2 and Model 1 (PT-501) systems
Kerry J. Morris reports: Oh yes, I remember it well..... (H)ome (E)lectronic (K)it compu(TOR) (!) or something similar. I used one myself, as a part of my OU (Open University) studies c. 1986, for the course 'TM222 - The Digital Computer'. I think they must have originally been developed around 1981. A bit clunky, I recall, but a great way of learning about microprocessor-based systems. In fact, I continued to use the HEKTOR user manual as a convenient and well written 8085 assembly language reference for about 10 years afterwards! I seem to remember that a few years ago, when the OU revised the courses which used HEKTOR, and wanted to replace the (by then) ageing technology, they gave students the opportunity to buy a HEKTOR system for a minimal sum (but I can't recall exactly how much). Since they were only for use with a few specialised OU courses, and were loaned to the students for the duration of the course, they are probably a bit of a rarity (at least compared to some systems), with perhaps no more than a few thousand ever made?
computer.name: Hektor 2
computer.ports: TV/RF output, composite video, cassette port, 40-pin interface for external peripheral board
computer.price: Unknown, available only on loan to Open University students

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD EXPLAINED</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Seems to be an I/O port plug<br> <b>(2)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug and remote relay<br> <b>(3)</b> Hektor peripheral board 40-pin connector<br> <b>(4)</b> 8155 I/O chip. Designed for use with 8085 processor. Features 256 bytes of RAM, a timer and I/O ports<br> <b>(5)</b> 8085-A processor running at 3.072 Mhz. Here a Toshiba version<br> <b>(6)</b> 2 x 2332 chips holding 8 KB of ROM (Monitor and assembler)<br> <b>(7)</b> Thomson SFF-93364 video chip<br> <b>(8)</b> 5-volt power regulator<br> <b>(9)</b> 1 KB video RAM 4118 chip<br> <b>(10)</b> 4 KB main RAM memory - 4 x 4118 chips<br> <b>(11)</b> TV aerial signals modulator<br> <b>(12)</b> Composite video RCA connector<br> <b>(13)</b> External power supply DIN plug and switch</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PERIPHERAL BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This board, used in conjunction with the Experiments books, enabled the student to use a microcomputer development system and then, design its own microprocessor-based product.<br><br> <b>(1)</b> Opto-detector disc<br> <b>(2)</b> motor<br> <b>(3)</b> Fan<br> <b>(4)</b> Heater bulbs and thermistor<br> <b>(5)</b> Heater control knob<br> <b>(6)</b> General analog knob<br> <b>(7)</b> Data switches and LEDs<br> <b>(8)</b> Ball pins and connecting wires<br> <b>(9)</b> 8155 I/O chip dedicated to various board instruments </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COURSE FOR ENGINEERS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Besides the usual User Manual, the Open University provided a complete course intended for computer engineers students.</blockquote>

computer.sound: Simple tone facility, played through TV speaker
